update.description:
The general idea here is put each of the `PostUpdate` calls \(for systems that implement them\) in their own worker thread. They are syncronized via two barriers \(which isn’t in the C\+\+ standard yet\).

Creating a thread and using a barrier ends up being slightly more efficient than the ign::common::WorkerPool, because we aren’t creating and destroying WorkOrders in each loop. This is only really possible because we’re making the same function calls repeatedly.

The barriers will block until all threads have reached the `barrier.wait()` call. This is why the barriers are constructed with a count of `number of postupdates + 1 (for the main thread)`

Edit:

This now includes a worker thread for rendering sensors, causing rendering updates to happen in parallel with the main thread.  In the case that a new rendering operation is required, the main thread will block until the previous one is complete.  

This generally eliminates frames that substantially overran their allotted time \(a rendering update could take 30-60x the allotted time\).
update.title: Add worker threads for System PostUpdate phase

content.raw: I agree its not entirely useful, but since all the postupdate threads are spawned at the same time, it really messes up console output.   Perhaps I can just keep it in this scope instead of making it a member.
content.html: I agree its not entirely useful, but since all the postupdate threads are spawned at the same time, it really messes up console output. Perhaps I can just keep it in this scope instead of making it a member.

pull_request.title: Add worker threads for System PostUpdate phase

pullrequest.title: Add worker threads for System PostUpdate phase

content.raw: Without requiring all systems to use this mutex, I'm not sure if it's useful to have here. In any case, I'd recommend using `std::lock_guard`.
content.html: Without requiring all systems to use this mutex, I'm not sure if it's useful to have here. In any case, I'd recommend using std::lock_guard.

pull_request.title: Add worker threads for System PostUpdate phase

pullrequest.title: Add worker threads for System PostUpdate phase

content.raw: Since the threads use a reference to the system, we should not allow adding elements to `systemsPostupdate` while the threads are running in `SimulationRunner::AddSystemToRunner` because it might invalidate the reference.
content.html: Since the threads use a reference to the system, we should not allow adding elements to systemsPostupdate while the threads are running in SimulationRunner::AddSystemToRunner because it might invalidate the reference.

content.raw:
I find it easiest to verify behavior with the profiler turned on:  

* When building for source \(eg with colcon\), add `-DENABLE_PROFILER=1` to the cmake arguments.
* Launch the profiler in a web browser: `xdg-open ~/workspaces/ign_blueprint/install/share/ignition/ignition-common3/profiler_vis/index.htm`
* Connect to the corresponding port \(1500 is default for server, 1501 for gui\)

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1839008168-2019-07-23-105713_1521x642_scrot.png)
content.html:
I find it easiest to verify behavior with the profiler turned on:

  • When building for source (eg with colcon), add -DENABLE_PROFILER=1 to the cmake arguments.
  • Launch the profiler in a web browser: xdg-open ~/workspaces/ign_blueprint/install/share/ignition/ignition-common3/profiler_vis/index.htm
  • Connect to the corresponding port (1500 is default for server, 1501 for gui)
